title: 108_s501
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program includes authorized activities to support these students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" recognizes the need for specialized services for gifted students from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or English as a second language. It highlights the advanced capabilities of elementary school gifted students and the varied needs of students in classrooms. Most teachers receive training to meet the needs of diverse students, but often lack training for gifted students. Public schools play a crucial role in providing services for high-ability students, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Parents are essential partners in developing appropriate educational services for gifted students. Gifted and talented students require access to information, research, and support for their educational, social, and emotional needs. There is no federal requirement to identify or serve the approximately 3,000,000 gifted students in the nation. State and local disparities in resources and services for gifted students exist, impacting their education and future success. It is crucial for highly capable students to receive an education that prepares them for innovative and creative work to meet the future economic and national security needs of the United States. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the United States on international assessments was low in physics and mathematics. Funding for challenging programs for gifted students was minimal in 1990. Competitive grants to states are authorized for educational agencies to support gifted and talented students. State educational agencies can award grants to local educational agencies for developing or expanding gifted and talented education programs and providing direct educational services and materials. Grant funds can be used for various activities, including providing direct educational services and materials. Grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for direct educational services and materials for gifted and talented students, such as curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. However, funds cannot be used for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. Additionally, a State educational agency receiving a grant under this chapter is limited to using no more than 10 percent of the funds for dissemination of program information and providing technical assistance. The chapter is about the use of grant funds for educational services and materials for gifted and talented students. It includes guidelines for the use of funds and the allocation of administrative costs. The chapter also covers the use of funds for monitoring and evaluation of programs, and the creation of an advisory board. From the amount available for this chapter, the Secretary reserves funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The remaining funds are allotted to states based on their populations aged 5 through 17, with a minimum grant amount set. Any unclaimed allotments are redistributed to other states. Any unclaimed allotments are redistributed to other states. SEC. 5467B outlines the state application process. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with assurances that funds will support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, be used for grants to local educational agencies, supplement existing funds, and provide matching funds. The State educational agency must provide matching funds equal to at least 10% of the grant funds received and develop program assessment models for accountability and effectiveness. The Secretary will approve a State's application if it meets the requirements of this section. "State educational agencies must allocate 90% of funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for grants to carry out authorized activities. Grants awarded should meet the needs of students. Local educational agencies must submit applications for funding." Local educational agencies must submit applications to the State educational agency to receive grants for identifying and supporting gifted and talented students. The application must include assurances on how the funds will be used, descriptions of meeting educational needs, and a commitment to supplement funds for gifted and talented students. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 requires annual reporting by State educational agencies on the number of students served and activities supported. The act allows serving gifted students alongside those with similar needs and ensures participation of private school students and teachers in grant programs. Definitions are provided for clarity. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 requires reporting by State educational agencies on students served and activities supported. The act defines 'gifted and talented' based on State law or educational agency definitions. 'State' refers to the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. Authorization of Appropriations: $170,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2004-2010. $7,500,000 for Chapter A and the remainder for Chapter 2. Technical amendments made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. In section 5461 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, "This part" is replaced with "This chapter". The term "this part" is changed to "this chapter" throughout the document. Section 5464 is amended by removing subsection (c) and renumbering subsections (d) and (e) as subsections (c) and (d).
